org.threadly.litesockets

Class Client

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.threadly.litesockets.Client
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    TCPClient, UDPClient

    public abstract class Client
extends java.lang.Object
    This is the main Client object used in litesockets. Anything that reads or writes data will use this object. The clients work by having buffered reads and writes for the socket. All reads will issue on a callback on a Reader in a single threaded manor. All writes will be sent in the order they are received. In general its better to write full protocol parsable packets with each write where possible. If not possible your own locking/ordering will have to be ensured. Close events will happen on there own Closer callback but it uses the same ThreadKey as the Reader thread. All Reads should be received before a close event happens. The client object can not functions with out being in a SocketExecuter.

      A simple byte counter to get rate states from a client.

    • Method Detail

      • getStats

        public SimpleByteStats getStats()
        Returns the SimpleByteStats object for this client.
        Returns:
        the byte stats for this client.

      • canRead

        public boolean canRead()
        Returns true if this client can read or false if it can not read any more data. This is in releation to the maxBufferSize vs the current readBuffer size.
        Returns:
        true if more reads can be added, false if not.

      • canWrite

        public boolean canWrite()
        Returns true if this client can accept more ByteBuffers to write. False is returned if the number of bytes pending write is greater than the max buffer size.
        Returns:
        true if it can write more false if it cant.

      • provideEmptyReadBuffer

        protected java.nio.ByteBuffer provideEmptyReadBuffer()
        When this clients socket has a read pending this is where the byteBuffer for the read comes from. It is assumed that this will only be used by the ReadThread on its socketExecuter and it checks to make sure thats the case. The ByteBuffer returned is not thread safe.
        Returns:
        A ByteBuffer for the ReadThread to use during its read operations.

      • addToReadSize

        protected void addToReadSize(int size)
        When a read is read from the socket the size of the read is reported to the client. This also reports the read size to the statistics of this client. This should be called by the client when the SocketExecuter calls addReadBuffer().
        Parameters:
        size - The size if the read in bytes from the socket.

      • addToWriteSize

        protected void addToWriteSize(int size)
        When a write is added to the client this is called to report the size of the write to the client. This write is added to the buffer size with this call.
        Parameters:
        size - The size of the write in bytes.

      • removeFromReadSize

        protected void removeFromReadSize(int size)
        This should be called when getRead() is called. This reduces the read buffer by said amount.
        Parameters:
        size - The size in bytes that is being removed from the buffers.

      • removeFromWriteSize

        protected void removeFromWriteSize(int size)
        This should be called when reduceWrite(int size) is called. This removes the size from the total buffer size and adds the write to the clients write stats.
        Parameters:
        size - The amount written to the socket.

      • getReadBufferSize

        public int getReadBufferSize()
        This is used to get the current size of the unRead readBuffer. If this is greater then the maxBufferSize the client will be removed from the SocketExecuters reading operations.
        Returns:
        the current size of the ReadBuffer.

      • getWriteBufferSize

        public int getWriteBufferSize()
        This is used to get the current size of the unWriten writeBuffer. If this is greater then the maxBufferSize the client will stop accepting new writes (except for forced writes).
        Returns:
        the current size of the writeBuffer.

      • getMaxBufferSize

        public int getMaxBufferSize()
        This is used to get the currently set max buffer size.
        Returns:
        the current MaxBuffer size allowed. The read and write buffer use this independently.

      • setThreadExecuter

        protected void setThreadExecuter(org.threadly.concurrent.SubmitterExecutorInterface sei)
        This is used by the SocketExecuter to set the ThreadExecuter this client is supposed to use. The ThreadExecuter works in a single threaded manor to keep all the client operations in order. This might need to be exposed to your package but in general You should not be assigning this or changing it.
        Parameters:
        sei - the ThreadExecuter to use for this client.

      • getThreadExecuter

        protected org.threadly.concurrent.SubmitterExecutorInterface getThreadExecuter()
        This returns the SubmitterExecutorInterface for this client. This executer works in a single threaded way so blocking this executer is very determinantal to the client flow.
        Returns:
        the ThreadExecuter for this client.

      • setSocketExecuter

        protected void setSocketExecuter(SocketExecuterBase ce)
        Sets this client to the specified SocketExecuter. This happens when the client is added to the SocketExecuter. This method should not be overridden.
        Parameters:
        ce - the SocketExecuter to set for this client.

      • getSocketExecuter

        protected SocketExecuterBase getSocketExecuter()
        This is used to get the clients currently assigned SocketExecuter.
        Returns:
        the SocketExecuter set for this client. if none, null is returned.

      • flagReadable

        protected void flagReadable()
        Used by extending classes to notify the SocketExecuter when this client can Read again.

      • flagWriteable

        protected void flagWriteable()
        Used by extending classes to notify the SocketExecuter when this client can write again.

      • callCloser

        protected void callCloser()
        The SocketExecuter calls this method when it detects a socket close event. This notifies the clients Closer if set.

      • getCloser

        protected Client.Closer getCloser()
        This is used to get the current Closer for this client.
        Returns:
        the current Closer interface for this client.

      • setCloser

        protected void setCloser(Client.Closer closer)
        This sets the Closer interface for this client. Once set the client will call .onClose on it once it a socket close is detected.
        Parameters:
        closer - sets this clients Closer interface.

      • callReader

        protected void callReader()
        This is used to notify the clients Reader that a read has been added

      • getReader

        protected Client.Reader getReader()
        Returns the currently set Reader callback.
        Returns:
        the current Reader for this client.

      • setReader

        protected void setReader(Client.Reader reader)
        This sets the Reader for the client. The Reader is called every time a new read is added to the client Each time a Reader is called it should call .getRead() *once* on the client
        Parameters:
        reader - the Reader interface to set for this client.

      • setMaxBufferSize

        public void setMaxBufferSize(int size)
        This allows you to set/change the max buffer size for this client object. This is the in java memory buffer not the additional socket buffer the OS might setup.
        Parameters:
        size - in bytes.

      • getRead

        public java.nio.ByteBuffer getRead()
        Whenever a Reader is called for this client a .getRead() should be called.
        Returns:
        a ByteBuffer of a read for this client.

      • addReadBuffer

        protected void addReadBuffer(java.nio.ByteBuffer bb)
        This is for the SocketExecuter. Once a read is done from the socket this is called. This call should also make a call to addReadBufferSize(int size).
        Parameters:
        bb - the ByteBuffer read off the Socket.

      • writeTry

        public boolean writeTry(java.nio.ByteBuffer bb)
        This will try to write a ByteBuffer to the client. If the current writeBuffer size is less than the Max buffer size this will return true. Otherwise you will get a false. If a false is received the buffer *will not* write to the socket unless you call another write again. It should be noted that either full parseable packets should be written at a time or some other form of locking should be used.
        Parameters:
        bb - the ByteBuffer to write to the client.
        Returns:
        true if the client has taken the ByteBuffer false if it did not.

      • writeBlocking

        public void writeBlocking(java.nio.ByteBuffer bb)
                   throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        This write will block until the write can be done. This block will only happen if the clients current writeBuffer size is more than the set maxBuffer. This block will persist either until the clients writeBuffer is less than the maxWriteBuffer or the client is closed. Care should be taken when using this. The pending writes for the client will happen on another unblockable thread but if a lot of clients use there read thread to write and block its possible to consume all threads in the pool. This is only a problem if the thread pool is reading/writting from both sides of a client connection using the same thread pool.
        Parameters:
        bb - the ByteBuffer to write.
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException - This happens only if the thread that is blocked is interrupted while waiting.

      • writeForce

        public void writeForce(java.nio.ByteBuffer bb)
        This write basically forces the client to go over its maxBufferSize. This technically does not have to be implemented by the client and can be dangerous if done incorrectly.
        Parameters:
        bb - the ByteBuffer to write to the client.

      • getWriteBuffer

        protected java.nio.ByteBuffer getWriteBuffer()
        This is called by the SocketExecuter once the clients socket is able to be written to. It is up to the clients implementer to figure out how to deal with combining or not combining ByteBuffers for write. In general its much better to just send the byteBuffers as they where received but the write functions.
        Returns:
        a ByteBuffer that can be used to Read new data off the socket for this client.

      • reduceWrite

        protected void reduceWrite(int size)
        This is called after a write is written to the clients socket. This tells the client how much of that ByteBuffer was written. This should also call removeFromWriteSize(size). to reduce the buffer and update stats.
        Parameters:
        size - the size in bytes of data written on the socket.

      • getChannel

        public abstract java.nio.channels.SocketChannel getChannel()
        Returns the SocketChannel for this client. If the client does not have a SocketChannel it will return null (ie UDPClient).
        Returns:
        the SocketChannel for this client.

      • getProtocol

        public abstract SocketExecuterBase.WireProtocol getProtocol()
        This is used by the SocketExecuter to help understand how to manage this client. Currently only UDP and TCP exist.
        Returns:
        The IP protocol type of this client.

      • getSocket

        public abstract java.net.Socket getSocket()
        Gets the raw Socket object for this Client.
        Returns:
        the Socket for this client.

      • isClosed

        public abstract boolean isClosed()
        Returns if this client is closed or not. Once a client is marked closed there is no way to reOpen it. You must just make a new client.
        Returns:
        true if the client is closed, false if the client is connected.

      • close

        public abstract void close()
        closes this client. Any pending writes when this is called will just be dropped.
